text: BB backlog, Bottle, pours a cloudy plum color with an average head. Nose has red vinegar, oak, brown sugar, sour cherry and other woody notes. Flavor is similar with some plum, wet oak, sour fruit, and rusty penny. The off sourness ruined it for me. Wondering about storage or its age. Carbonation was also lacking.
Hazy pour nose our sour fruits mostly lemon. Taste real tart and wine like with the funk going on. Excellent!
Bottle at What The Funk. Pours a clear copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is sour fruit, oak, vinegar. Thin mouth, tart fruit, oak, light funk, very nice.

2010 Vintage. Pours a rusty sienna color with a finger of gaseous foam that settles out quickly. Layers and layers of dried berries, composted apples, wet hay, soft bourbon, vinous acidity and musty basement funk. The softness and complexity of this beer was the highlight and there are no words to describe this unique quality, but the underlying flavors that come together to build the base of this amazing beer are worth the mention; tart cherry, wet wood, bitter walnut, dried plum, horsehair, leather, lemon zest, orange zest.

Bottle shared thanks to Lukaduke! Piurs dark red brown with small thin bubby head. Nose is rich, old tart funky dried dark fruit, leather, earthy nut, wood, cherry, berries, raisin, spice. Nose is a little sharp right out of the fridge but opens up nicely after a few minutes. Taste has dark fruit, grape, earthy wood spice, dark bread, tart cherry and mixed berries. Finish is semi sweet leathery old fruit, forest tree, earthy dark bread, raisin, woody funk. Delicious!

Tap @ Jolly Pumpkin: 2013 release. Cloudy mix of deep copper, red-tinted brown & nearly amber towards the bottom. Thin, small, gray-tinted bubbly film across the top. Lovely sourness from the first whiff. Acidic tartness, vinegar, strong vinous wood, oak, red grape, bombarding with tannin. Deeper notes of black cherry skin, apples, & a mild horsey barnyard twinge lingering on the backside. Wow. First sip is crazy sour. Puckering to the max. Vinous red wine notes, sweet grapes, soaked wood, tannic oak, balsamic vinegar, stone fruit, under-ripe & exceedingly tart plums. Acidic on the palate without burning the guts too much. A bit of cherry & lemon, just a hint of lactic acid near the finish. Slight cascade of wet hay, musty wood, & a touch of barnyard. Just enough funk to keep things interesting. Sharp mouth feel; light with a bone-dry finish. Incredible beer, one of JPs best.

"dont know what makes this a BDG and not a wild/sour. pretty dang good either way. multiple bugs give this a deep, complex array of sour flavors with a bit of a sweet backbone. almost wine like. oak and acidity at the fore. good beer."

Such a nice boubon oak aroma from this dark orange brew with little head. Some lemon tarness came throgh as you bring it closer. Dried fruits in the falvor with musty basment and funk. Drier finish tahn most bourbon brews...I consider that a plus...Great brew

Similar to the base beer, only with a touch of bourbon. Dark fruits, a hint metallic, dark cocoa, quite tart. Dark sours are generally not my thing, and this one has very solid flavors but still falls short of greatness, which for me is like 4.3+ territory.

Tangy fruit nose some woody toasty notes a little vinegary maybe. Definitely oxidized and metallic. Copper pour thin head. Flavors of sour dark fruits wood kind of a metallic mouth feel. Woody barrely interesting. Balsamic with some astringency in the finish. Meh. Lingering metallic mouthfeel.
Foamy head with a vinegar sour aroma, but a mild sour flavor. Has a brown gold color and a slight bitter hop long finish. A pleasant sour.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle from 2010. The aroma is slightly acidic, bourbon, cherries. The flavor ischerries, soft oak notes, malty, berry. This is tasty, but it is not overly complex. I feel that it is missing something, maybe past its prime?

Shared by JCB. Clean soft copper brown pour with 2 finger off white head. Phenolic and tart nose with some dry funky notes. Very tart in the mouth with some acetic notes and a touch of burnt grain. Floral esters show too with some sweet fruit. Very tart on the finish. Awesome.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Matt. Big thanks man!! Clear orange appearance with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Sour oranges, grapefruit, vinegar, oaky, lightly spicy, a touch of caramel, and toffee in the aroma. Taste is sour fruit peel, orange juice, grapefruit, heavy oak, a hint of pepper, funk, and red wine vinegar. Light body with medium carbonation.
Bottle at CGBD. Pours gold with a white head. Oaky and lightly fruity, with medium tartness, wood, and hints of vanilla. Really damn delicious.

Thanks Tooch for the bottle. Bottled March of 2011

A - Pours a cloudy plum purple / red. Decent head that fades fast.

S - Nose is great. Big cherry pie and sour cherries, figs and an oaky rodenbach nose. A slight bit of copper penny.

T - very nice. wow. Exceptionally tart and dry finish. I instantly get a bit of heartburn which is troubling but to be expected..(better go grab some tums). Lovely lemon and fig qualities. There is some vinegar but not much.

M - Medium bodies, slick and not too carbonated

O - Great beer. Great serving size. nice and drinkable on a cool summer evening.
#4400, sample at The Festival. awesome beer. sour cherries, tart acidity, bourbon notes. complex and balanced. need more of this

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep caramel/amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flflavor have a wonderful tart cherry character, oak, light vinegar, some of the Jolly Pumpkin funk, even a mild vinous note. This is a crazy drinkable beer. I just wish I had more of it to drink.
Pours a hazy dark red with a off white head. The aromas are wonderful, sour cherry ,oak, dark fruits and vinegar. Acidic, balanced with a great tart finish. Amazing beer.

Bottle from 2010 - thanks Deyholla! Pours hazy reddish chestnut with almost no head and only a thin ring of beige foam around the glass rim that does manage to leave a bit of lacing. Aroma is wood, bourbon, tart cherry, funk, somewhat vinaceous - red wine. Flavor is much the same, light to medium sweet and corresponding tartness, tart cherry and bourbon notes forward, with funkiness coming in later along with lemon rind to provide just a pinch of bitterness. Woody notes linger to the finish, but do not bring much associated astringence. Medium body, basically flat in the mouth. Very nice tasting; I just wish it had maintained some carbonation.

This was courtesy of Darren proprietor of The Local Beer Bar in Eureka, my favorite watering hole.  Pours a dark amber with a very small off-white head. The nose is funky and sour.  Seems like there is some wood.  . Medium body with smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is quite sour and shows wood for sure.  Lots of  sour fruit. Finish is sour and very tasty.  Really delicious sour ale.
Bottle 4/24/10 316/318 (Courtesy of FlandersNed at DLD)-Pours amber. Aroma of yeast. Taste of the same. This full Bodied brew was nice but missing the bourbon.

2011 bottled provided by Matt. Sampled side by side with a 2012 Biere de Mars. Pours a murky brown in color with a soapy ring around the glass. Nose is full of oak, vinegar, some cherry, and sweet malt. The flavor is slightly more sour than the regular biere de mars as well as more astringent. There is light malt vinegar character to it as well.  Mouthfeel is light and moderately acidic, low to moderate carbonation, and a short finish. I think I almost prefer the regular biere de mars to this. It has more balance and is a little less harsh on the palate.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours somewhat murky brown/reddish with very low white head. Low lacing. Aroma is of dark fruits, sourness, malt, intense fruits, sligth phenol. Taste is of sourness, fruits, JP signature. Palate: Ligth body. Overall: Pretty good, refreshing.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by Julien, Pier-Luc and Benoît, thanks! Amber brown with almost no head. Aroma is clearly Jolly Pumpkin with lots of red bruits, acetic notes and can be compared to a good flemish red. Bourbon is barely noticeable. Taste is about the same as aroma. Moderate sourness. Mouthfeel is dry and acetic. Almost no carbonation. Interesting Sour in the Jolly Pumpkin mold. It was have been more intriguing with the bourbon being a little more present.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep amber with a purple hue and a grayish head that starts at the edges and dissipates completely. Aroma has a nice sour red fruit note with a bit of vinegar and a strong oaky backbone. Flavor begins with acid and vinegar but mellows out to more of a sour red fruit and a oak backbone.

Bottle. Pours reddish amber brown. Nose/taste of cherry vinegar, tart red berries, oak, vanilla, brown sugar and tannins. I dont get any of the bourbon from the barrel treatment. Aggressive acidity up front. Settles down after a few sips. Medium body.

330ml bottle thanks to Auoracrisis. First off, this beer was fantastic, just wonderful but I am already biased towards the regular biere de mars which we rarely see in Colorado. Dark red with a healthy head at first that died quick. It smelled a lot like the regular version, sour flanders style beer. The taste however had a very pronounced and beautiful oak flavor to it that complemented the beer very well. Sour but full and not so much the lemon flavor I have detected in Biere De Mars. I was actually astonished by how much better it was with the extended oak aging. Fantastic beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-19-2011 19:28:16

Shared with Mike and Matt. Served side by side with Biere de Mars.

The beer appears a slightly darker brown than the Biere de Mars, with a bit less head and lace. The aroma is funky, with a strong lactic, acetic presence. It smells similar to Russian River Consecration, which is definitely a good thing. Oak, slight vinegar, tart, Brettanomyces, acetic. Definitely worth a try if you are a fan of funky, sour beers.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-13-2011
Pours with no head. Im missing the bourbon here. I get the acidity but pretty one-dimensional. Easy-drinking but missing something.

Bottle at home. Pours hazy reddish amber with a small creamy beige head. The aroma is balsamicco, vinegar, fruit, wood and light bourbon. The flavour is at first very acidic and sour but then comes fruit, wood and light pepper. Very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 12 oz. Pours ruby mahogany with a creamy beige head leaving lacing. Aroma is buttery creamy sweet sour acidy oaky dill a bit vinous and damp cellar. Flavor is a bit thin, acidy sour sweet fruity in front, oaky vinous astringent bitter cellar from middle ending more astringent dryish bitter. Finishes dry oaky bitterish with a touch of fruits.

330ml bottle shared by JulienHuxley. Recent batch (65).
Appearance : Clear amber with tiny head.

Aroma : Great sourness, brown sugar, lots of oak. Slightly vinegary.

Taste : Oaky and tannic. Sour and acidic. Brown sugar with some fruits. Some dark cherries. 

Overall : Really complex and hard to describe. Fairly light on the sourness for a JP but its a good thing for me. Really interesting and well done. Fairly well balanced.

Small bottle. Dark brown/mahogany pour, no head. Aroma is lightly sour some flanders red notes a bit of cherry, some vinegar. Taste is sour but not extremely so, some brown sugar, a tad cherry, very woody. Palate is a bit flat, med body. I remember this being better, Ill give it a rerate.
Bottle. Hazy murky, reddish brown. Aroma of sour berries with some vinegar in the background. Taste of vinegar, berries, quite sour. Medium bodied, long pleasant aftertaste. Really enjoyed this one.

From notes.

Batch 472/473 3-22-2011
8/4/9/4/17

My pour is a murky brown color;  the pour is a little darker, fuller, and less transparent than the regular beer.  A small off-white ring forms around the edge of the glass.

The aroma has a bit more vinegar burn than the regular Biere de Mars.  Lemon, 

The flavor is much more sour than the regular Biere de Mars.  The lactic sour notes are still presence, but there is a bit more vinegar sourness.  Lots of lemon steps in the front and really takes the place of the dried dark fruits.  A fit of faded caramel malt is noticeable in the background, but the full, robust sour flavor has really taken over in a delicious way.  

Being more sour than the regular Biere de Mars, it is no surprise that it is more puckering on the palate.  It starts out smooth and a bit sweet, with a lemony sourness that grows, peaks, and levels off  at the end, finishing cleanly.  The body and carbonation are both on the light side of medium.

Biere de Mars is a great beer, and the Grand Reserve improves it nicely.

Good amount of cranberry, vanilla and oak in the aroma. Flavor has much of the same and finishes sharp and dry. Hoping to have more of this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[4169-20111203] Tap. Grainy saison yeast aroma. Hazy, dark amber brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Yeasty orange fruit flavour has a quick but interesting sour yeasty finish. Medium body has a funny sour note. Tasty. (8/4-/8-/3/16) 3.9
(w/ jerc, rudolf)

Batch 346/348, Bottled 2-19-10
Tasted on 2/11/12 from a 330mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours hazy dark auburn with a thin, bubbly off-white head that leaves thin, bubbly lace.  The nose is sour fruits with the Jolly Pumpkin funk that I love, along with some oaky vanilla and coconut notes.  The flavor is pretty much the same with the sour fruits, funk, oak, and an added bread malt.  The body is medium with just lighter than average carbonation, and a long sour, funky, and oak influenced finish, with some nice tannin.

Bottle, courtesy of bushmat1. Batch 472/473. Thanks so much, Matt! Oaky, dark cherry, dark raspberry, fairly tart aroma. Tangy, moderately tart raspberry/cherry/plum, moderately sour, rich fruity flavor thats very smooth. Tart, black cherry aftertaste. Great beer! Thanks again, Matt!

Batch 472/473, 2011 bottle huge, huge thanks to Matt for cracking this one.  Gushed a tiny bit, but nice dark reddish pour with white head, aroma has notes of vinegar, acetic notes, hints of oak, red grape, tannic oak, really nice smelling.  Taste is nice sour cherry, dark fruit, hints of oak and vinegar notes, touch of  tart fruit and lemon, finishing really dry and oaky.  Delicious!

2011-12-03. Hazy red tinged dark brown body, tiny beige head. 3+ Modestly oaky aroma, sour fruit, hints of lemon and cherry. Complexity of the oak grows as you go. 7+ Flavour is similar, steady oak presence, lemon sourness, pithy lemon, lemon and grapefruit seeds, modest sourness lingers pleasantly. 7+ Smooth average plus palate suits the beer, soft carbonation. 3+ Pretty nice, refreshingly sour. Bottle via trade with FlandersNed

Bottle, huge thanks to Jer & Karen.  Hazy ruby mahogany body, thin white head.  Nose is lemon & oak, a bit boozy, sweet malt.  flavor follows, lemon & wood, nice acid but a strange booziness Im not a huge fan of. Nice, but a bit harsh.

Bottle: Poured a dirty cloudy beige color ale with s mall bubbly head with limited retention and not much lacing. Aroma consists of sour and tart notes with light oak notes. Taste is quiet sour with some light oak and light funky yeast notes with a mild acidity level. Body is quite full with low carbonation. I tasted more funk then bourbon to be honest but very enjoyable beer from one of my favourite brewery.

Bottle courtesy of Sean shared at 3F.  Reddish/brown pour with an off white head.  Sour woody aromas.  The taste is really interesting with cabernet, sour stone fruit, funk, and woody notes.  Good stuff....

Original batch, Hazy dark golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of wild yeast, wood, leather, toasted malts, and light fruits. Taste of yeast, bacteria, wood, vanilla, citrus, and a tart finish.

(11.2oz bottle courtesy of ray101! Batch 472/473.  Bottled 3.22.2011).  Pours a cloudy dark amber/mahogany color with thin off-white head.  Aroma has some wonderful pit fruit, wood, vanilla and a touch of caramel. Taste is sour-acetic with lots of tart fruit.  Awesome!    Thin bodied with a dry, woody finish.  JP really nailed it with this one.  Love it!

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2012 (Bottle) Pours dark reddish brown with a small head. The aroma holds woodsy citrus, spices, light funky/horse blanket,  lots of woodsy bourbon/oak, mould, medicine and tiny hints of old hops. Nice, but not super complex nose. The flavour is dry and near heavily acidic with almost no bitterness. Citrus, light funkiness, light medicine and crackers. The mouthfeel is tart with light carbonation. Lingering, aggressive citric and medicine-like finish. Light to medium bodied.

Nom nom nom. Dark fruit acidity with an ultra vinous nose, with mounds of pleasant acetic acid, and cherries. Not overly complex, but gets away with it quite well. Low carbonation and a medium body lead to a hyper dry finish.

Small squat bottle. Pours a dark walnut color with minimal head. Nose is wonderful; great funky cherry sour presence, the flavor bringing excellent vinous notes, a touch of vanilla and wood, and great dry funk. Lovely.

355mL thanks to FlandersNed. The pour is a tepid mahogany to red. No head formation. Yellow bubbles come to life. The nose is sharp oud bruin: wet oak, spicy oak, cinnamon, chocolate, red grape acidity. Salty caramel and toffee come through. Taste....wow so easy to drink. Softly tart with quenching salty sourness. No excessive vinegar/acetobacter. Mild "heat" from the sourness. Not too much different from the normal BdM. Both are excellent dark sours. This one, though, is just extremely easy to love. It has zero metals or earth I remember in the normal version. This is all tangy grapes, wet spicy oak, plums and black raspberries. You could chug an entire bottle or two non stop. Im not kidding. I would shotgun this beer at parties. Like a boss.

Bottle shared by GT2.  Pours clear to lightly hazy mahogany with a small, fizzy off-white head, medium-short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is tart fruits, vinous, oak and caramel, biscuit malt, and barnyard notes.  Flavor is caramel and biscuit malt with sour fruits and oak notes with a dry finish.  Medium body, low warmth, medium carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of GT2, thank you sir!  Clear dark amber brown, scant white head. Aroma of sour orange and Grand Marnier, prunes,  raisins, vanilla. Taste is nicely sour stone fruits with a nice dry and sour kick at the finish.  Bourbon is perfectly subtle  Nice stuff.

Cask at Great Taste. Pours a somewhat ugly reddish brown, on the paler side with a soap bubbled film on top. Nose is striking. Dark cherry, vanilla & wood come through, then a yoghurt sourness. Not much vinegar to speak up, seems to have been mostly lacto. On taste, crisp sourness that works well agains the sweet base beer and the bourbony char notes from the oaky. More vanilla and cherry/plum as it progresses. Finishes reasonably dry. Excellent beer.

GTMW.  Deep red-brown.  Dark/tart fruit, musty funk, mild vinegar, and barrel notes.  Deep, dark merlot-like flavor that ends with a crisp, tart sour finish.  Black cherries and wood.  Mellows well as you drink.  Nice rustic complexity.

Draft on tap at Great Taste of the Midwest 2011 (Madison, WI). Pours a murky darker amber pour, a golden glowing bottom and edges with a loose bubbled whitish head. Small, aromas are rich red wine, cherries, touches of apple, pear, wet oak, vanilla, some funky brett, dry. Nice, a mellow red wine feel and fruity esters. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied, cherries and red wine, some vinegar moving into some lemon, brett, and it gets earthy into the backend. Not too acidic, actually quite drinkable. Nice red wine presence, lactic acid, touches of vinegar, nice. Really nice oaky pressence, powerful assertive sourness that doesnt tip the scales into that overly acidic range. Quality, one of the best sours of the day.

Sampled on draft at GTMW 2011. Pours a hazy copper with a large fizzy tan head that fades quickly. Aroma of tart cherries, berries and citrus. Extremely tart taste is berries, cherries and faint wood. Medium bodied. Very nice.

Bottle thanks rciesla for bringing it to the tasting. Brown hazy pour with some tan head. Aroma is of brett, lacto, fruit, and light malt, with some lighter oak. Flavor is sour fruit, light oak and a touch of bourbon.

MiBG Summer Fest 2011. brownish orange body. sour funk, berry and citrus in the nose...all bathed in an oak bath. vinaigrette in the nose as well. flavor is heavy cherry, yeast, and vinegar with subtle fruit and oak.

On tap at MBGSF 2011.  Pours a cloudy amber, having a sour apple aroma.  Flavor has the sour apple, some caramel tones, berry, and oak.  A mostly acetic but still somewhat lactic sourness.  Very nice.

On tap; pour is murky golden brown with a modest beige head that retains very modestly in this glass. The nose is floral, vanilla, oak, spices, and vinegar. This brew has a fantastic, smooth mouthfeel, with a slight bitter acetic bite. Vinegar, vanilla, dark fruits, earthy oak, caramel; amazing basically.

2000 ratings!  Heres to 2000 more on ratebeer!  11.2 oz bottle from fbm115.  Thanks man!  Dark, ruddy reddish pour with minimal head.  It pours almost still with what ends up being a thin white rim around the glass of a head.  Some mild swirls of stray bubbles at the surface of the beer.  Strong sour component to the aroma.  Wet wood, cherries, citrus, and tart funk.  Some mild yogurt and vanilla.  Flavor is tart and funky, like sour ales should be.  Lots of Vanilla, oak, mild smoke.  Notes of tart cherries, sweaty funk, blackberries.  As well as some dark fruit.  Finishes tart with a rush of bourbon.  Slick mouthfeel.  Wonderful, wonderful beer.

33cl bottle pours a hazy, copper amber, clumpy white head.  Nose is awesome, sweet, tart, cherries, light citrus, some light malt, yeasty, funky, a little horsey.  Flavor is more mild, lightly sweet, lightly tart, some citrus zest, a little apple, some light wood.  Full bodied, tart, lightly acidic finish.

Bottle from triptens...thanks Joe! Batch 346/348 bottled on 2-19-10. Pours hazy mahogany with a thin ring of large khaki bubbles. Black cherries on the nose with red wine-soaked oak, lightly tart funk, and a ton of malt. Light booze thats a bit sweet but also with a dryness to it. Weird. Oak is stronger in the taste, with tons of malt up front, then citrusy tartness. Finishes pretty sweet, with orange rind and some oak sharpness. Pronounced yeast on the long finish. Pretty sharp carbonation and a light body. Good, but I actually preferred the regular Biere de Mars.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Linh, James, and Andrew before Explosions In The Sky. Pours a hazy walnut tan with fluffy, tightly-bubbled white lacing. Aroma is dark cherries, currants, plums, chestnuts, soil, deeply moist oak, vanilla, and subdued Brett notes. The carbonation on this brew is mild, but it tempers well with the subdued oaky, vanilla, and cherry flavors. The finish is mildly tart with some huge, bready, malty notes in the finish. Great brew.
Courtesy of JRedmond.  Interesting brew... Pours brownish.  Tamely carbonated.  Plums and sour cherry.  Oaky and sweet.  Reminds me cuvee de tomme meets calabaza..
Bottle split with Linh, pat, and Andrew. Pours a hazy brown body with nice white lacing. Aroma and flavor are a great combination between sour, tart, wood, dark fruit, and light Bourbon notes.

Bottle into a Bells tulip...A medium brown with a little amber in it, muddy color, light tan head, ok carbation, decent lacing...Aroma is decent funk and oak. In reality it smells like every other Jolly Pumkpin beer, they all have the same oak backbone, this goes a little further adding a little vinegar and tart fruits. Better than the average jp...Taste is pretty good, again a lot of the jp oak but more complex. 

Most jp beers are blah to me but this is something Id like to have more of.

Bottle at Argo0 pre-RBSG tasting on 13 July 2006. Pretty much as I anticipated from Jolly Pumpkin, which I had heard a lot about. Mushroomy and barnyard notes on the nose. But a bit more restrained than I expected. Moderate funky farmyard character on the palate. There was a slightly odd edge that I thought seemed a bit like plastic but it didnt detract too much. Moderate sourness. Sharp mouthfeel. The bourbon aging contributed just a slight accent without overwhelming. Perhaps it smoothed things out a bit too. Good but I was expecting something a bit more extreme.

Traded 12oz stubi bottle. Pours out a nice darker brown with amber edges and a thin tan head. Looks slick. Big, almost pungent, sour aroma but you can still smell the base beer too.  Similar flavor with a blast of tart, acetic sour and then mellows into a nice brown ale. Short finish. It will make your mouth water I promise.

12 ounce bottle thanks to footbalm, an older vintage the one with the mistaken label. Pours a light brown color with a light white head. A sour Flemish brown nose, some bourbon. The flavor is excellent; not overly aggressive, but smooth, woody, vanilla, caramel, toffee, sweet sour malts. Slightly tart, but not acidic. Nice. A really good brew.

11.2oz bottle, batch #346/348 dated 2/19/10, courtesy of iceicebaby on BA. thanks, sean! pours a dark, hazy, burgandy-brown with a thin, whispy, off-white head and sticky lacing. aroma is great with big, bold, tart cherries, wet oak, and barnyard funk backed by sour mash bourbon, lemon zest, and interesting pumpkin pie spice notes with traces of red wine vinegar and brown sugar. flavor is delicious as well, not as harsh as expected, with tart cherries, balsamic vinegar, and tannic red wine up front backed by sweet chocolate, oakey bourbon, dry yeast, and nougat on the back end. palate is medium bodied, dry, and nicely carbonated with a mildly tart, woody finish. overall, a damn nice wild ale.

12 oz bottle given to me by northernbrews.  Oak with hints of bourbon on the nose with traces of acidic tartness.  Pours a reddish brown with a very thin off white head.  Tart oak upfront, acidic with traces of tart raspberry and strawberry, with oaky vanilla and just a hint of bourbon with a very crisp dry finish.  Just a wonderful beer, a great mix of tart fruit and oaky bourbon with a great dry finish.  Awesome1
330 ml botle.  Clear dark chestnut pour, light tan head.  Vinegar, fruit, acidic, cherry, heavy bread, oak, and light bourbon.  A nice sour ale, on the heavy, dark side. Well done.

12 oz. bottle; 2010 release, batch 346/348; some light orange funky gunk on the bottle neck and cap; pours clear dark brown with trace white head lingering along the edges and as a thin film; sour cherries, oak, mango and creamy vanilla on the nose; yummy sour oak, lemons and zingy cherry/almost chocolate combo; earthy funk, dried cherries; very light bourbon sweetness with orange peels, white grapes and woody lemons; enjoying much more than previous sample of batch 65; zesty citrus fruits, caramel, light sour lemon; thin, dull texture is almost leathery; a very clean tasting sour with muted complexity; subtleness is quite welcome in comparison to the punch you in the face sour; very nice IMO in this relatively fresh state from the recent release; thanks Derek!!

Original Rating 7/10/08 (Score - 3.5): 12 oz. bottle - batch 65; pours flat and dark brown-orange; slight haze against the light; some sour aromas, but more musky, woody and almost like dirty feet; thin body and lots of sour and funk, and also vinegar; bourbon influence not very noticeable and pretty much smoked against the LA Red Poppy; too vinegary for me

Pours a reddish copper with an off white head and a good amount of lacing as it goes down. Nose is incredibly complex. I get tart green apples, ripe cherries, brown sugar, hints of caramel, a bit of vinegar, and maybe a little bit of lemon. Taste draws all the flavors together quite well and adds a bit of extra funk. Mouthfeel comes from both acetic and lactic sourness. Quite drinkable, although maybe a bit over the top in any relatively large quantity.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-28-2010

bottle poured a red brown in color with a thin covering of off white head. aroma has deep yeast, mild funk, sour cherry, light acidity, and a light barrel wood. mouth feel is light and the carbonation is very low. flavor gives a nice initial pucker, loads of interesting yeast, oak, sour cherry, and a creeping acidity. this is smooth and has plenty of barrel and yeast flavors that play well together and stand out at the same time.

12 oz. bottle shared by lushawn- thanks, Shawn!  He always manages to cross beers off my Wants list.  Marked with a sticker saying it was aged for 16 months.  Pours a cloudy reddish-brown color with a small khaki head.  Aroma of oak, vanilla, grapes, grapes, tart apples, and plums.  Flavor of vanilla, grapes, oak, plums, tart apples, toffee, lemon juice, and brett.  Funky and sour, but also shows a lot of the barrel.  Light-bodied, with low carbonation and a thin, watery mouthfeel.  If this had managed to hang on to some body, I probably would have liked it more.  As it stands, its a pretty neat, complex, all-over-the-place beer that I was happy to try.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 Bottle from thecheeseman.  Thanks!!!  Pours  a cola brown with copper red highlights and a tiny offwhite head. 16 month batch.  Aroma of red grapes, vinous,  chocolate covered cherries.  Taste is a balsamic bourbon, sour vinous borbon red wine concoction.  Some nice leather and plastic funk comes through as it wearms.  Chocolate cocoa and sour cherries mellow into bready winelike dough.  Neat, layored beer that morphs quite a bit as you drink it. Thin body.  Dry.  Tasty.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a head that dies quickly and becomes a thin ring of off-white head.

S: The oak and lactic acidity are quite evident on the nose. A bit of sweet caramel and vanilla, as well as some light funkiness. Some hints of sour cherries and vinegar, as well.

T: Oak is dominant throughout and provides a tannic quality to the beer. Some light vinegar and and cherries, but not overly sour or tart. Theres a distinct earthiness to this beer which I find enjoyable.

M: The body is medium with a soft carbonation and lightly dry finish.

D: Like most of Jolly Pumpkins beers, this is a good one. I havent had the regular Biere de Mars, but this has inspired me to pick one up at some point.

Bottle: &nbsp Brown in color, reddish/caramel hue, thin sudsy off-white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Pretty much what I expected for being aged this long. &nbsp Strong oaky nose. &nbsp Not getting much Bourbon. &nbsp Just seems very woody. &nbsp Smooth on the tongue, woodiness overpowers everything else. &nbsp Underlying Biere de Garde doesnt really show through, no big funkiness. &nbsp Very tart, fairly dry. &nbsp Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Really smooth and clean. &nbsp Didnt seem too complex, but for it being woody it was very enjoyable. &nbsp Thanks to Pailhead for the bottle!

355ml bottle from northernbrews. aged 16 months. big bold flemmish red. shows a ton of barrel character but the base beer shines through the barrel. huge sour, berry forward, complex aged red ale. a great late night sipper and truely a world class flemish red.

There were 2 bottles of this shared at a tasting.  One was a sour and the other was aged on a bourbon barrel.  2 different beers and should have 2 different listings.  The bourbon:  had a great bourbon aroma, mouthfeel was medium, has great notes of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and finishes semi sweet.  The sour:  smelled acidic, tart, woody, and funky.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavors were very sour, tart, funky, just all around a great beer as well.

Bottle courtesy Sean.  Batch 346/348.  Oak, tart, funky cherry, and lemon sugar aroma.  Smooth semi-sour cherry taste with a zippy tart finish.  To some degree, a rounder, mellower Red Poppy IMHO.  Tart smoothes as the beer warms and the oak holds the various components together quite well.  Great beer.

Batch 65, aged 27 months.  Pours a hazy reddish amber.  Aroma has tons of oak and sour funk, with a bit of cherry.  Taste does not have as much vinegar as I would expect for something this acidic.  Vinous, with tons of oak, tart fruit, medium to low sweetness, sour and tart.  Finish has tart lemon and grapefruit peel with oak and barnyard funk.
Pours deep brown with scarlet glow when held to the light. Thin tan head. Nose is tart cherry, oak and subtle bourbon. Same in the flavor with more vinous influence. Clean dry finish.

Batch 346/348.  Bottled 2/19/10.  Courtesy of mikey711.  Dark brown pour with red streaks and topped with a thin head.  Sour cherries in the aroma along with vinous notes, old wood and funky barrel notes.  The barrel aging has definitely mellowed this out.  Heavy oak and barrel flavors along with tart red fruits, some funk, plants, and black plums on the back end.  This is good but not a world class offering like I was expecting.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a woody tart sour aroma. Fruity woody malty vanilla flavor with tart hints and hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty woody tart sour finish.

330ml bottle from my Secret Santa - thanks, deyholla! Dark brown pour with moderate carbonation, and a very inviting nose that is super woody and funked up, with hints of pert fruit and breads as well. The mouthfeel is very pleasant, with a slightly vinous quality to it and a dry pucker of a finish. The flavor is delicious, dominated by that nicely aged acetic quality and that dry woody sharpness that I love from JP barrels. Deeper into the flavor you get hints of lemon, leather, tart cherry, and hints of fruitcake too. Terrific stuff, if in a wee bottle.
A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Reminds me of abbaye st bon chien, quite tasty and different from most american sours.

Batch 65 aged 27 months, tasted 7/3/10

Brown pour, modest head despite an aggressive pour. Acetic acid and cherries on the nose, maybe some wood, but a surprisingly hard-to-find bourbon character (it picks up more on the aroma of the empty glass; I think perhaps the acetic acid covers).  Characteristic JP green apples, some cherry, of course very much an acetic Flemish-style sour though not sweet in the least; instead, one gets a mouth-puckering,drying tannin close. The midrange actually recalls Alexander (though perhaps Im just imagining that) in its tannic cherry intensity. Almost none of the caramel and brown sugar that makes the regular Biere de Mars so confusing stylistically. Over all, the beer is very good, but not quite the standout I might have hoped for.

330ml bottle thanks to sarro on BA.  Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a one-finger light tan head that fades to a ring.  Jolly Pumpkins house yeast is evident on the aroma.  Pretty funky and oaky with caramel malt.  Flavor is slightly sweet caramel malt but mostly tart and full of the house yeast flavor.  Funky and oaky with some slight fruity notes and very slight bourbon.  Nice palate, dry and fairly tart with medium body.  Pretty good beer.  Not amazing, but good.

Bottle from the more recent batch.  Murky brown with a faint copper hue. Great nose of dry oak, faint citrus and a touch of sour cherries. Very similar on the palate, lightly acidic, not quite as sour as I was expecting, damn tasty though.

12oz bottle courtesy of Derek - batch 65.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a small fizzy tan head that recedes quickly to a small collar leaving spotty lacing.

The aroma is full of the oak - spicy with some leather undertones.  There are some tart cherries and a bit of earthy funk as well.

The taste has a bit more funk than the aroma, especially in the finish.  There is also lots of barrel character and sugary fruits and sweet malts in the background.  Definitely a wine character to the whole thing but with a moderate bourbon presence.

Again, the mouthfeel is very vinous - dry and oaky in the finish.  Soft carbonation and medium bodied overall.

Man, I havent revisited Jolly Pumpkin and I forgot how good their stuff was.  This is a fantastic oak aged beer and super drinkable.
Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting. - funky, bretty, tart and caramel malts. Very good, though I feel like this has been done before.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle.

Batch 346/348. The beer pours light brown with a white head. The aroma is tart with some lemons, yeast and oak. The flavor is brown sugar, lemon, brett funk and oak. The tartness lingers and makes the beer very drinkable. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(11.2oz bottle via trade with BA gratefulbeerhead batch 346/348 bottled 2-19-10) clear medium brown with oily bubbles on the edges. Nose of raisin, brown sugar, tangerine, yeast, light metal, and funky wet barrel. Taste of brown sugar, vinous, light sourness, light vinegar. Soft carbonation with a tart linger.

Bottle (bottled 2-19-2010 Batch 346/348) thanks to thirdeye11. Pours with a small off-white head over a brown body. Aroma of brown sugar, wine, oak, and florals. Taste is brown sugar, oak, light funk, vinous, sour and some vinegar. Light bubbles. Nicely acidic.

big thanks to thirdeye11 for this one, batch 346/348.  poured a deep brown with a few cream bubbles.  funk, tartness, brown sugar, raisins, and dried fruits on the nose.  great on the palate, flavor is lightly tart, acidic, dried fruits, wood, and funky in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2011 batch 65.  hazy pour, med carbonation.  color of a roasted cinnamon stick
nose: caramel and apple cider vinegar.  cinnamon, apple pie with a buttery crust.  any malolactic fermentation on this guy?  baby doll hair, but not floral sweet plastic like my little ponies.  parrafin, old lipstick.
mouth: upfront sweet/sour like lemonade, light, mid caramel oakiness.  fuller weight.  initial sourness dies and gives way to a slight creaminess.  again, malo??  yeastier pours give good texture and body.  back palate is sour, finish comes in BIG, cider vinegar overwhelms other flavors, but caramel/oak/dill comes through as acidity dies.  finish is nuanced with lingering caramel apple. 
OMG DELICIOUS EAT IT

Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting.  Pours a hazy brown with a thin white head.  Gorgeous classic Jolly Pumpkin funk with a pile of caramel and toffee.  Medium bodied, soft and buttery with some nice funk and light bretty tartness.  Long slow soft tart bitter and funky finish.  Really yummy.

In short (16 months in oak):: A dry roasted woody bourbon semi-funky, semi-sour ale.  Good brew 
In short (batch 65 27 months in oak): A sharp, dry, sour, fruity ale with whiskey notes.  Kick-ass
How: Bottles 12oz.  Age unknown.  I drank both versions (16 months in oak & 27 months BA batch 65).  Multiple bottles from multiple sources (toncatcher/Dennis, Solan/Alan, ygtbsm94/Brad, others?).  Thanks to you all.
The look (16 months in oak): Cloudy dark amber ruby topped by a small persistent beige head
The look (batch 65 27 months in oak): Cloudy golden amber body topped by an off-white ring of foam 
In long 16 months in oak:First I was very surprised to notice a lot bourbon in the aroma of the 16 months BA version and very little bourbon in the 27 months BA version.  Go figure.  Nose has roasted wood and bourbon.  Taste is dry roasted malts, roasted wood, backed fruits, some red apples, lots of whiskey barrel, a tiny bit of smoke.  Very dry.  Barely sour, not really funky.  This beer does not resemble the regular JP BDM at all.  Did I get a bad bottle? 
 The look (batch 65 27 months in oak): First I was very surprised to notice a lot bourbon in the aroma of the 16 months BA version and very little bourbon in the 27 months BA version.  Go figure.  Nose has sharp funk.  Taste of 27 months BA is funky, lots of green sour apples, light single malt whisky notes, some vinegar.  Very dry.  The bourbon barrel in this one was really like sour oak and a drop whiskey, not whiskey barrel wood like with the 16 months BA.  The caramel of the regular JP BDM is really town down here.  I really like the regular JP BDM but if I can say one bad thing about it is that the caramel and funky sourness dont really work well together.  This beer is just as sharp, funky and sour as the regular JP BDM except that the caramel is toned down and the added bourbon notes are moderate.  So I found this one better than the regular BDM.
Score for (16 months in oak): 7-3-8-3-15 = 3.6
Score for  (batch 65 27 months in oak): 9-4-8-4-18 = 4.3
In conclusion: The 16 months version couldnt lace up the batch 65 boots.  Well, of course I know a beer doesnt really wear boots.  Its a figure of speech.  However, I like to put my bottles in a thong when I cellar them.

Served on cask.....Pours a deep, dark brown with amber and red hues....beautiful cascading off-white head when poured from a cask. Smells amazing of tart acidic cherries, oak, leather, Brett, and maybe some apple cider or red wine vinegar. Taste incredible with acidic and acetic sourness... Cherries and some lemons... Lots of great oak and leathery notes with a strong underlying Brett backbone... Mouthfeel on cask is so nice and creamy... Medium-full bodied perfect for this type of sour... Not spritzy or light or highly carbonated like some American wild ales and all the RR -tion sours....drinkability is amazing. Drink it all day if not for the heartburn that would set in after about 3-4 glasses. Most similar to cuvee de tomme, due to its heavy flavors and beautifully melded sour characteristics....although very uniquely Jolly Pumpkin if you know what I mean !

Batch 346/348.  Bottled 2-19-10.  Slight gusher.  Pours a dark mahogany color, with a small short-lived off white head.  Deep oaky aroma with lots of vinousness, cider vinegar, some cherry, a hint of molasses, vanilla, spice, caramel, and that distinct JP house funk.  Immensely acidic sour flavor that blends sweet caramel, dry tannic pinot grapes, lots of oak, alcohol, black pepper, warm spices, vanilla and a dry bretty finish.  Medium body with soft carbonation.  Wonderfully complex and balanced.  Every sip is uncovering more and more flavors.

Amber pour with a tiny beige head.  Aroma is tart, with some light cherry and lemon and a bit of acetic acid, some paint thinner.  Flavor is rich and tart with a touch of booze, lemon rind, cherry pits, sour leather and some earth, spiciness.  nice barrel notes but the boozy bourbon is a little overpowering.    Tasty

Bottle from SoLans Moms son.Pours a thick, viscous amber sap with a stark aroma of sweet and sour cedar and maple syrup.  A nice wallpaper of oak hangs in the background.  Flavor is an immediate rush of lemonade served in a cedar tumbler.  Tart, woody cherries quickly emerge and then settle in the moist earth tones of French countryside soil in a woody forest. at the finish of each sip.  A zesty, tingly and thick syrupy feel on the tongue.  Yet another great Jolly Pumpkin offering.  Id like about 100 of these to cellar.

text: Bottle.  "16 months in oak" on neck.  Nose is a "whoa" ... Lively, funk, vinegar, fruits, oak teem up upon opening.  Prickly carbonation that softens quite a bit upon warming up.  Flavor is pretty spot on w/ nose... fullness of the oak comes through with high temps... funky and tasty.  But flavor doesnt linger nor does it jump out all that much.  An easier drinking, super tasty sour ale ... very well integrated and balanced.  A winner.  Would prefer a tad more oak, just for shits.  In a phrase - "Cuvee de Tomme light" ... delightful.

Thanks to TampaBrew

A: Pours an amberish hue with a small off white head.

S: Blend of sour fruits, oak, vinegar, and loads of funk.

T: Mild sweet fruit notes before the acid and sourness plows through. Vinegar is there along with nice bold oak and even a bit of bourbon.

M: Medium for the style, goes down pretty easy.

D: Good another tasty rare Jolly Pumpkin treat.

This one poured a murky reddish color with an off white head. Aroma was some sour funk, barnyard, bittering hops, and bourbon. In the taste, the bourbon came through a bit more than I would have liked and covered up some of the expected citrusy funkiness in this one.

Bottle from Styles. Thanks man. More than expected. Pours amber with a slight off-white head. Sour funky aroma. Maybe some wood. Medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is sour and woody. Lots of fruit. Could be cherry. Or not. Finishes decently sour and woody. Really tasty sour ale.

Batch 65 bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours orange amber with almost no head and a strong oak aroma. This one was even more sour than I thought it would be. Since I love sour ales, I was ecstatic. The flavor is quite fruity with considerable oak presence, some whiskey, and a bit of vinegar. Its an excellent brew. Thanks, Bill.

Sour apple with slight lactic edge on the aroma.  This carries through to the flavor but with a mild wood cask finish.  Apple cider color.

Notes: 2006 release (3 yrs old) t the Pints for Prostates/Denver Rare Beer Tasting at Wynkoop Brewing Co, 2009 Great American Beer Fest

Special aged bottle from Beerman 6686 at the Pgh RB gathering 12/09.  Funky old smell. Sour and bitter commencement. There is a little more bitter bite than I care for but the funkiness arouses me. Funky barnyard bitter tartness on my palate. Good overall sour beer experience. Bitter lengthy linger.

text: Backlog. Orange pour with a white head. Aroma of musty malt, sour fruits and oak. Flavors of tangy/sour fruit, oak, and caramel malt.  Medium/light body sour/malty with a sour/malty/woody finish.

Thanks to thecheeseman for this one!  Light and hazy pour with a thin off white head.  Aroma is vanilla, cherry and light bourbon.  Light oxidation with hints of cherry, vanilla, green apple and cereal.

Bottle 12fl.oz.Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sour, fruity - berry, wine, wood, strawberry. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090913]

Good lord this was delicious.  Brownish pour. Aroma is full of bourbon, sour cherries, fruit vinegar, wood and maybe some vanilla.  Flavor is sweet tart, vanilla, wood, bourbon, just delicious.  Really well done.  This was a bottle of the original batch.  And it is still amazing.

12 oz bottle from WTF OMG tasting. Pours a hazy golden yellow color topped by a small, foamy off white head that settles quickly to a thin film. The aroma is really nice with notes of soured apples and other tart citrus to go with some funky wood characters and the sour mash and vaniila from the bourbon barrel. The flavor follows with more tart citrus and sour green apples mixed nicely with soem funky oak tannins, and a touch of bourbon. Some vanilla from the oak comes through as well and smooths out the tart flavors. Full bodied and mouth puckering tart with ample carbonation leading to a lengthy sour apple finish. I love the regular Bier de Mars, and this one is just even better. Fantastic sour ale, and the best brew from Jolly Pumpkin that I have had.

Courtesy northerbrews. 16 months in the barrel. Brown. White carbonation. Beautiful combo of well funked sour ale and bourbon barrel- fruity, tart, barn, vanilla, coconut, a touch of booze. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Awesome.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange red coloured with a small off white head.
Fruity aroma of bourbon, vanilla and dried fruits with notes of caramel.
Fruity flavour of brett, bourbon, spices and vanilla.
Tart finish.
Hazy burgundy with a medium beige head. Sour aroma with lacto, sour berries and roasted malt. Flavour was sour with lacto, sour cherries, wood and banryardy notes. Finished sour.

clear reg/brown smooth offwhite head.
very nice balanced sour aroma, aged, blended smooth.
flavor is sour, bitter, smooth, fruity. quite blended.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Beige dense head. Berries, sourness, wood, light sweetness, grapes in the aroma. Flavour of sourness, berries, grapes, light wood. Medium to full bodied. Dry. Grapy and sour berry end. very nice.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small white head. Aroma is dry acidic and slight wooden aroma. Mild cherry fruity note. Smooth cherry and vague fruity touch. Mild citric to acidic with lingering dry wooden note and light malty touch. Ends dry and slight acidic.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2009 Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours a clear warm amber with a small off-white head. Very enticing sour, woody aroma. Medium body, caramel, sour fruit and wood, the Bourbon does shine through the sourness. Sour, sulphurous finish. Wonderful. 130909

gold label on my bottle says 16 months in oak. not sure which version this is. DEEP burgundy pour with a beige head that didnt last very long. Aroma if loaded with oak, red wine vinegar, and some balsamic vinegar with a light fruitiness. Flavor is robust, and extremely tart. Lots of fruit, like cherries, and plums, but the oak just dominates the finish. Slight vanilla, in the end. Its semi dry, and the oak lingers. I like it. its a sipper even at 7%.

14 months on oak. hazy copper with a fleeting head. Big citrusy sour cherry spicy aromas with sharp oxidized caramel. Light/medium body. Sour cherry, sharp caramel with tart and dry spicy red wine flavors and some vanilla sweetness. Like to try the more recent batch...

text: Bottle from Secret Santa, thanks! Dark brown color. Overwhelming vinous aroma with grapes, hints of toffee and dust. I can hardly get my nose out of the glass. Vinous flavor with oak, grapes, caramel. Earthy with some dried fruit. Apple. Moderate sourness. Excellent brew, complex and with an almost perfect aroma.

Bottle, hooked up by Tronraner. Pours red with tons of floaties. The aroma is very sour with true vinegar, musty basement, oak, grapes, grass. Carbonation is lively. The flavor has hints at cranberries, cheese, vinegar, oak. This is one solid beer. Im surprised to see this is bourbon aged, I dont get any flavors that would lead me to guess that.

Bottle, thanks to 2009 Summer Secret Santa, shared with NachlamSie. Ive been looking forward to this one. Pours a dark rust color with a finger of beige head. The aroma is musty funk, currant, oak, sweet rye bread, some brett, and lots of vinous nuances. The flavor is oak, white wine, currant, and a pleasant farmy tartness. Some vanilla, honey, and grass notes come out with time. The finish is quite dry and clean. Extremely good beer, I wish I had more.

Bottle batch 65 courtesy of styles. Oak wooden barrel along with lot of sour for aroma. Caramel colored body held to light a firery orange and this disapating head on pour. Flavor had some serious sour pucker to it. Sour pears and abundane of tart to go along with some cotton candy. A good candy caramel from last three swigs a plesant suprise. Leaves the palate sour tart and dry. Thanks Chris.
Bottle...  Poured amber with an off-white head.  Tart and oaky.  A little bit of an alcohol warmth and a grainy, puckering finish.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 16 month bottle thanks to kryptic!Pours a little darker than the original, still semi-transparent mahogany with a beige head, slightly smaller. The bourbon knocks out some of the fruity nose of the regular and creates a creamier, more simple profile, but there is still ample brett influence in lemon, also some light wood and similar spice. The harmony in the brett-bourbon marriage is very impressive and is present in the nose and flavor. Mouth also is a hint sweeter, slightly more vanilla and bourbon to add to the tart notes. Very woody, also some refreshing lemon. Carbonation is lower, which is better given that it doesnt compete with the flavor. Shorter finish due to the lack of the fruit, but definite brett influence here as well. Overall still great, but I think the fruit qualities of the regular are lost here, and unfortunately the beer becomes less interesting as a result. 06/11 - 16 month looks nut brown, frothy small white head, little lacing. Dusty, peppery nose, plum and sugary bourbon, lighter vanilla and oak, bit sawdust and lotion. Flavor really oaky, light sugar and licorice, bit thin and hot. 948416.06/11 - 27month has similar pour as 16mo, white head dies a bit, tepid. Lightly citric and woody nose, less bourbon than 16, more sour, swirls reveal rich bourbon, plum, sugar. Flavor similar, balanced, light acetic coupling with red berries nicely. 849517

shared a 12 oz bottle with MereLikesBeer. This stuff, as epic as I thought it was going to be, really didnt blow me away. Yes, it was very aromatic, and intensely sour and complex, but to me, it was too much like their La Roja, and I think there should be a little more variety in JPs brews. If you get the chance though, you should get check this out. Cheers! Happy 250th beer rating!!

Yet another exceptional beverage from the great people at Jolly Pumpkin.  This is my third from them, and clearly not my last.  I picked up a bottle of this with my friend BeerBaron617 a few days ago at the brewery and were waiting for our 50th (my 50th and his 250th) to rate!  So...Here it goes!  This poured a great dark amber and there was quite a bit of sediment hanging out in the glass.  The head quickly went away but was a light tan color to begin with.  Smelled like a nice red wine with dark fruit aromas.  Super oak aroma - very woody.  Very carbonated but leaves a sweet flavor in my mouth and its really juicy.  I am really happy I had the opportunity to try this out.  Cheers to Jolly Pumpkin.

Bottle thanks to Scott.  Pours a deep burgundy with a soapy head.  Nice oak aromas, with some brown sugar and darker fruits.  Big oak up front, typical of the better aged Jolly Pumpkins.  Finish is long and sour, with a little heat from the bourbon.  Carbonation is a tad high, even for me.  Some burnt candies and tobacco start to appear.  This is an interesting take with the bourbon, and its quite good.  But these weird off flavors kind of keep creeping up in the finish.  Not perfect but interesting and solid.

Bottle Batch 65 shared by alexsdad06.

Poured a clear dark brown color with a minimal frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate to heavy tart citrus, good funk and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long  duration.

This is a standout beer for style. Thanks Brad.

Have 16 months on my notes. Lots going on. Wood, some alcohol. Dark fruit with some faint sourness and musty quality. A little bland for what is is. Dry finish, drinkable but lingers on the tongue, a bit prickly.

Bottle thanks to thecheeseman,  always nice trading with that guy...Pours brown with a nice beige head.  Aroma was similar to standing in a wood warehouse.  It definitely wasnt just oak I was getting.  Lots of funkiness in the nose as well.  Flavor was up front great.  Typical jolly pumpkin house flavor with a nice oaky background.  Plenty of funk,  and some dark fruits.  That is short lived though,  and the beer just gets in your face woody with nothing to really balance it out.  Very tanic,  and just a brutal finish.  This one was interesting.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of sour fruits, cherry, bourbon, oak and brett funk.  Super sour greatness.  Medium hazy amber brown hue with a small off white foamy head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is sweet, sour, and smooth with hints of bourbon.  Palate is light-medium bodied and lively.  Finish is smooth.  Very good brew with a nice sour bourbon character.  Just fantastic.

Pros: Gorgeous look.  Well established, layered foam.  Expressive aroma.  Excellent density in the mouth.  30+ second finish leaves lingering oak nuance on the palate.  Fully flavored, lots of depth.  Very balanced, well executed.  

 

Cons: Not a single flaw that I can detect.  

 

What a beauty.  Thanks, Derek.

Bottle, courtesy sebletitje. Brownish red pour, thin white lacing, thin white head. Big oak and sour vinegar in the nose, bretty sweat, some dark fruit. Oak flavors, some tart notes, wheat and fruit, dry wood. Underwhelming flavor compared to the nose, not very easy to drink.

Bottle, courtesy northernbrews and GodOfThunder! (no batch number, says 16 months in oak) Pours a dark amber, low haze, off-white head with some nice lacing. On the nose yart, acidic, some nice acetic hints, a little bourbon, wood, vanilla, solid caramel malts and the bretty JP funk. Quite tart, puckering, with a nice dry finish, lots of tannins, sour with a soft wood and vanilla in the finish. Manages to be both drying and lush carbonation. A little thin in the mouth. Excellent, tarter more tannic version of their standard BdM.

Northernbrews is the man for hooking us up with this!  Serious funk in the nose, with dusty blueberries and vanilla.  Flavor is dope.  Sour, fruity, funky and oaky.  Very nice.  One of my favorite JP offerings.
Bottle courtesy of artusory. Pours a deep amber. Reaks of sour and brett. Light wood flavor, sour vinegar, sharp lactic acid flavor.

Bottle courtesy of sebletitje. Pours a dark amber color with thin head. Aroma is sweet and sour malt, floral, tart, brett yeast, some notes of vinegar and wood. Flavor is overripe and sour fruit, more vinegar, some notes of brett, wood, some hints of bourbon. Generally medium body with a tangy finish.

Wow, thanks sebletitje for the share.  Pours dark cola brown with an off-white head.  Nose is vinegar, malt, sour fruit, brettanomyces, and oak character.  Flavor is vinegar, sour fruit, brett, cobweb, and noticeable malt.  A good and enjoyable sour.

courtesy of frampin. thanks for this amazing extra.
This sure is a Jolly Pumpkin sour.
Pours cloudy brown with thin white head.
Aroma has again the JP signature, lots of funk as per usual, yeast, fruit sourness and for that long of aging the wood was very light in the nose.
Taste, sweet light sourness and wood barrel palate. Bourbon comes in and is mixed with the fruit sourness with a bit of a dry finish.

Another off my want list thanks to Styles.  Botle batch #65 aged 27 months.  Dark amber color with no head.  Taste is vinegar dried fruit nmaybe plums and cherries.  Some noticable alcohol. Another huge hit for JP.

12oz bottle found in a box while cleaning. Original batch, 12oz. Pours a dark red color with an off white head, about 1/4 inch that stays throughout and is frothy. Lots of bubbles and sediment rip up to the top. Nose is light alcohol, some apricots and raisins, also some dank yeastiness notes and a harsh kind of cherry nose bite. Palate is full with some fizziness and a clean but biting finish. Flavors are heavy on cherries and apricots, light, dried fruit notes with an alcohol warming that is not unpleasent. Fairly mild, but still a good biting sensation.

Bottle thanks to Goldtwins.  Pours red brown with small head.  Sour nose with hints of cherry.  Flavor is very tart up front with sour cherry and wood that hit you next.  Very acidic that makes the mouth squeeze tight, but still wanting more.  There is an something odd in the finish that I cant put my finger on.  Kind of metallic ending.

Batch 65 Bottle generously shared by beastiefan2k. Dregs pour: looks like a dark apple cider with a thin off-white ring of head clinging to the glass. The nose is of sour fruit vinegar with a tart cherry-like note in support. Light to medium-bodied and quite tart with a dry, puckering finish. Sour cherries and fruit vinegar with a solid, tart finish. This is a nice sour. Thanks again for sharing it with us, Eugene.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2010 Batch 65, from Styles, thanks a lot man.  Color is dark copper almost brown, very clear.  Aroma is light cherry sour with fruit vinegar and very stingy on the nose, the vinegar grows strong. Taste is very stingy vinegar with light fruity tints. With a long sour, tart, and acidic finish.  There is just a bit of buttery barrel essence throughout but not enough to interfere with the beer.  Long tart dry finish.  Much better than the other GR beers I have had with the least amount of barrel and particularly barrel sugar in it. 12oz bottle in a Cantillon copita  glass. 8/3/8/4/16Re-rate: from Mike, thanks a lot.  Split with Brandon.  I might have liked this before but it is way too acetic for me now.  Not sure if it my tastes of the beer itself changing over time.  The flavor is not as acetic, more lemony but still plenty of acetic vinegar. 6/3/7/3/14
